column1: The following are common causes of broken bones: - Fall from a height - Motor vehicle accidents - Direct blow - Child abuse - Repetitive forces, such as those caused by running, can cause stress fractures of the foot, ankle, tibia, or hip
If necessary, call 911 and begin rescue breathing, CPR, or bleeding control.
- Apply ice packs to reduce pain and swelling.
(For example, if the fracture is in the leg, press on the foot).
Signs that circulation is inadequate include pale or blue skin, numbness or tingling, and loss of pulse.
- DO NOT move a person with an injured hip, pelvis, or upper leg unless it is absolutely necessary.
- DO NOT move a person who has a possible spine injury.
- There is a suspected broken bone in the head, neck, or back.
- There is a suspected broken bone in the hip, pelvis, or upper leg.
If a young child refuses to put weight on an arm or leg after an accident, won't move the arm or leg, or you can clearly see a deformity, assume the child has a broken bone and get medical help.
